I have four milsurp rifles for sale. I prefer to keep them together as a collection, I'll explain a little more below.All four rifles have strong rifling and shiny bores. From top to bottom:1936 Moschetto Modello 91 da Cavalleria. Gardone Val Trompia manufactured. 6.5 Carcano. This is the Carbine with an underfolding bayonet and has a transitionary bayonet catch that uses a lever instead of the later pushbutton and earlier lug style making it somewhat rare. There is a crack that has been repaired behind the receiver tang and the rear sling attachment in the buttstock has been filled. A handy rifle given to mounted, paratrooper, mechanized, and alpine Italian troops. 1942 Round receiver wartime production so its kind of neat to see the rough machining. Tula Arsenal. All matching. Comes with bayonet, tool kit, sling, cleaning rod, and cleaning kit. 2 stripper clips
1938 round receiver peacetime production and it shows in the machining of its round receiver, especially when compared to its wartime counterparts. Tula Arsenal. Matching bolt and receiver but force matched magazine floor plate. Comes with a sling and cleaning rod. 2 stripper clips
1926 hex receiver. These are a world apart in my opinion from the round receivers. The soviet stampings are far more refined. These were built on much older 1891 dragoon and full size rifle receivers. Also has an imperial tsarist eagle on the receiver so clearly from before 1917 originally. Tula Arsenal. Matching bolt and receiver but force matched magazine floor plate. Comes with bayonet, sling, tool kit, and cleaning kit. 1 stripper clip
As stated, I would prefer to keep all of them together. I bought these over a period of time in order to eventually build a complete collection. These each have different types of receivers that reflect the decade they were built. They also have all three types of 91/30 stock sling variations represented. partial metal pressed, full metal pressed, and full metal screwed. As a result I've enjoyed them as representative of a broad range of 91/30 types and a modest collection that can be built upon with other mosin nagant models. They just seem to work as a set.With any milsurp rifle, its impossible to say for certain but I believe that all four of these guns certainly saw action in at least one world war and in the case of my imperial russian receiver mosin and the carcano, even earlier. The Mosin being pre 1917 and  Italy getting busy in east and north Africa in the late 30s. I believe I have priced the set for less than individual asking prices here and eleswhere. I might consider selling individually at a higher per unit cost.Thank you for taking the time, Im happy to answer any questions you might have and can of course provide more pictures by request.
